Incident.Summary: The suspect was arrested for DUI/ DWI.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
In-car camera operational, T-6. BWC utilized.

Defendant: James Timothy Buckler
Soundex #/State: MD-10272874120/Maryland
Date of Birth: 01/18/1966
Date of Arrest: 02/06/2023
Time of Arrest:  1421 Hours
DUI #23-015

Narrative:

     On February 6, 2023 at approximately 1410 hours, I, TFC Engleman #7197 along with Tpr. Pettyjohn #7329 were operating my unmarked patrol vehicle traveling southbound on MD RT. 245 (Hollywood Road) approaching Wheatherby Drive, Hollywood, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20636. At that time, I observed a maroon pickup truck in front of me begin to weave within its lane of travel. The truck crossed the solid white shoulder line with both passenger side tires and then moved immediately towards the center of the roadway. The truck then crossed the center hashed/solid yellow lane lines with both driver’s side tires into the oncoming traffic lane for approximately three (3) seconds.

     We then continued to follow the vehicle and observe its driving habits. While still traveling southbound on MD RT. 245 passing Tin Top Hill Lane, Hollywood, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20636 the truck began weaving within its lane of travel again. The truck crossed the solid white shoulder line with both passenger side tires for approximately two (2) seconds, corrected back into its lane of travel, and then crossed the shoulder line again with both passenger side tires for approximately four (4) seconds.

     Tpr. Pettyjohn who was operating my patrol vehicle under my supervision as his field training officer, activated his emergency equipment and conducted a traffic stop on the vehicle. The vehicle came to a stop on MD RT. 245 at Speith Road, Leonardtown, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20650. Tpr. Pettyjohn made contact with the vehicle’s operator who was identified as James Timothy Buckler (WM DOB: 01/18/1966) by his Maryland driver’s license. During the course of the investigation, Tpr. Pettyjohn learned Buckler had previously consumed alcoholic beverage's prior to driving. Tpr. Pettyjohn conducted standardized field sobriety tests on Buckler under my supervision. For results of the tests, see Tpr. Pettyjohn’s supplemental report.

     After completing the standardized field sobriety tests, I asked Buckler if he would consent to a preliminary breath test. Buckler consented to taking the preliminary breath test. The result was 0.13 BrAC. Tpr. Pettyjohn then placed Buckler under arrest for Driving Under the Influence. Buckler was transported to the Leonardtown Barrack for processing and later released to a sober driver. See Tpr. Pettyjohn’s supplemental report for arrest disposition and processing.

Case closed by arrest.

All of the above events occurred in St. Mary’s County, Maryland.

In-car camera operational, T-6. BWC utilized.

Defendant: James Timothy Buckler
Soundex #/State: MD-10272874120 / Maryland
Date of Birth: 01/18/1966
Date of Arrest: 02/06/2023
Time of Arrest: 1421 Hours
DUI #23-015

Vehicle in Motion (Phase 1):
    On February 6, 2023 at approximately 1410 hours, I, Tpr. Pettyjohn #7329 along with TFC Engleman #7197 were operating my unmarked patrol vehicle traveling southbound on MD RT. 245 (Hollywood Road) approaching Wheatherby Drive, Hollywood, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20636. At that time, I observed a maroon pickup truck in front of me begin to weave within its lane of travel. The truck crossed the solid white shoulder line with both passenger side tires and then moved immediately towards the center of the roadway. The truck then crossed the center hashed/solid yellow lane lines with both driver’s side tires into the oncoming traffic lane for approximately three (3) seconds. We then continued to follow the vehicle and observe its driving habits. While still traveling southbound on MD RT. 245 passing Tin Top Hill Lane, Hollywood, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20636 the truck began weaving within its lane of travel again. The truck crossed the solid white shoulder line with both passenger side tires for approximately two (2) seconds, corrected back into its lane of travel, and then crossed the shoulder line again with both passenger side tires for approximately four (4) seconds. I then activated my emergency equipment and conducted a traffic stop on the vehicle on Hollywood Road at Speith Road, Leonardtown, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20650. The vehicle was identified a maroon Chevrolet S10 bearing Maryland registration “7AL9034.”

Personal Contact (Phase 2):

     I made contact with the driver of the vehicle via the driver’s side window. The driver was identified as James Timothy Buckler (W/M DOB: 01/18/1966) by his Maryland driver’s license. I advised the driver he was stopped for crossing the double yellow line. I observed the driver’s speech to be slurred while speaking with me, glassy eyes, and a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and vehicle. I asked Buckler where he was coming from and he stated, “Calvert County.” I asked Buckler how much he had to drink tonight and he stated, “I had a rum and coke at lunch time.” I then gathered the remainder of Buckler’s information and asked him to exit his vehicle, to which he complied. I then asked if Buckler if he would be willing to conducted standardized field sobriety tests to which he consented. The results are as follows.

Pre-Arrest Screening (Phase 3):

     The evaluation was performed on a driveway entrance, next to my patrol vehicle on the side. The surface was dry, level, and free from any debris or obstruction. Lighting conditions consisted of natural sunlight with my front emergency lights deactivated. Buckler appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible injuries, limps, or limb ailments. (Reference below for more information regarding any medical history or injuries).
I asked Buckler the following questions:
  • Contacts or eyeglasses: Buckler wears eyeglasses and was wearing them at the time of the stop.
  • Medications: Buckler stated he takes Xanax, and Percocet for a leg injury he had 10 years ago. Buckler also stated he takes Seizure medication. Buckler stated he took his medication this morning.
  • Medical conditions or injuries which would inhabit his ability to walk in a straight line or stand on one foot: Buckler stated he has a bad weakness in his right leg due to a leg injury 10 years ago.
     It should be noted, while speaking with Buckler outside of the vehicle I detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person.

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (6/6 clues observed)

     The first test was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The black tip of my pen was used as a stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Buckler’s face. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the black tip of the pen with his eye’s until told to stop. Buckler’s pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking and no resting Nystagmus was observed. I asked Buckler if he understood the instructions and he stated, “Yes sir.”
  • Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes
  • Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation – Present in both eyes
  • Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degree – Present in both eyes
*Vertical Gaze Nystagmus – Not present
It should be noted, while conducting Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus Buckler kept looking away at passing vehicles.

Walk and Turn – (4/8 clues observed)
    
     Prior to Buckler performing the test I explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Buckler was instructed to place his feet together and place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe and imagine a straight line in front of him. Buckler was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and to remain in this position until told to begin. Buckler was advised to take nine (9) steps in a straight line, touching heel to toe on every step. Buckler was advised to keep his hands flat at his sides, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and count every step out aloud. On the ninth step Buckler was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line and take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to turn completely around. Buckler was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. Buckler was instructed that once he began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his sides, look down at his feet, and count each step aloud. I asked Buckler if he understood the instructions and he stated, “Yeah.”
  • Instructional Stage: After being instructed the starting position, Buckler broke the starting position one (1) time.

Walking Stage (1st Nine Steps):
  • Steps of line on step’s seven (7) and does not reset back on line.
  • Missed heel to toe greater than one half (½) an inch on step’s three (3), four (4), five (5) six (6), seven (7), eight (8), and nine (9).
Walking Stage (2nd Nine Steps):
  • Missed heel to toe greater than one half (½) an inch on step’s two (2), three (3), four (4), five (5), six (6), seven (7), eight (8), and nine (9).
  • Stops walking on step’s two (2), and three (3).
  • Steps of line on step’s two (2), three (3), five (5), and six (6).
Turn:
  • Nothing to report
    
One Leg Stand (0/4 clues observed) - *CANNOT DO THE TEST*
     After being instructed on how to do the test, Buckler stated he was not able to do it because of his leg injury.


Arrest:

  Based on the following, I had reason to believe Buckler was driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:
  • Strong odor of alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath
  • Eyes glassy
  • My observed clues of impairment while he performed field sobriety tests
  • Failure to maintain lane
     I arrested Buckler for driving under the influence of alcohol at approximately 1426 hours. I then secured Buckler in the front passenger seat of my patrol vehicle (T-6), seat belted him normally, and transported him to the Leonardtown Barrack for processing. Buckler did not place any items in his mouth or remove anything from his mouth. A mouth check was conducted at 0227 hours. Nothing was located inside his mouth. During transport I played the English version of the DR-15, Advice of Rights via the MVA website. After arriving at the barrack, I gave Buckler a copy of the DR-15 to review. After Buckler reviewed the DR-15, Advice of Rights, he signed his consent to submit to the intoximeter test. The breath test was administered by Sergeant Oles #5857. The breath specimen was found to contain an alcohol concentration of 0.11 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath.

  All copies of the paperwork were completed and given to Buckler for his records. Buckler was released to a sober driver, from the Leonardtown Barrack.
Charges:

  Buckler was charged with the following citations:
  1. Driving while under the influence of alcohol (3GVOVNP)
  2. Driving while under the influence of alcohol per-se (3GW0VNP)
  3. Driving while impaired by alcohol (3GX0VNP)
  4. Negligent driving (3GYOVNP)
  5. Reckless driving (3GZ0VNP)
  6. Driver failure to obey properly placed traffic control device instructions(3H00VNP)
  7. Failure to drive vehicle on right half of roadway when required (3H10VNP)
Case closed by arrest.

All of the following events occurred in St. Mary’s County, Maryland.
